With these choices you can access almost any site with the exception of parts of sites that use Adobe Flash which is no longer supported on Android after version 4.  There are also apps for accessing your email which provide access to almost any provider.  Please understand that if you are a power email user, you will have to use the browser to access full GMail functionality, which is easy to do.Apps:One of the first things you will want to do is disable the feature that allows only Amazon store apps.  This way you can put apps like Nook or Zinio on your Kindle Fire HD.  Now you have a fully functional tablet...  But seriously folks, the app store is not as full as Google's store but for most major apps if they exist in Google's store, they will be published in Amazon's store too.Hardware:In general, the device feels solid in your hands.  It weighs in at 20 oz which is a little heavy.  The speakers are nice quality and sound clearly when used with clean country music or distorted head banger styles.  The 1.5 GHz Dual core processor is more than enough to power this device for personal use as an e-reader or personal web browser and email.  It powers the music and video with great quality giving the user High Definition on a 8.9" screen.Screen:The screen is amazing in that it is brilliantly colorful, has a great resolution, and is easy on your eyes during reading.  With a resolution of 1920 x 1200 you will easily be able to watch videos in full HD brilliance and to be honest anything beyond this resolution in this size of a screen is overkill that is just using more power.  The glass is strong, but I would recommend a case and a screen saver to prevent scratching.Battery:Battery life is great in the device and you could easily fly from New York to Los Angeles on one charge.  The device recharges quickly when you use the additional cost charger which is a must buy unless of course you have existing Samsung or Motorola mobility devices that use micro USB in which case you can share the cable and chargers with your new Kindle.Wi-Fi connectivity:The new Dual Band capability is a big benefit as most routers contain G and N functionality allowing for greater range of connectivity from the wireless base station.Memory:With options for 16GB or 32GB you will have plenty of room.  People fail to realize just how big a GB is.  For the average person 16GB will more than do.  If you are a music nut or video freak there is the 32GB option, but to make your life easy Amazon includes free Amazon Cloud storage for media purchased from their store.  This is great because you can access your movies from XBOX, Roku or Google TV devices.

Reviews.Title: Great value, beautiful device for media.
Reviews.Author: Tracey Fox
Reviews.Content: I have the 7" Kindle Fire HD, and love it.  When I decided to get something larger to use for out of town travel, I considered just about everything out there, but ended up purchasing the 8.9" Kindle Fire HD.  I couldn't be happier! I put my hands on as many tablets as possible in the stores to make sure I was making an informed decision.  I even considered plunking down $600+ on the new ipad with retina display; also seriously considered the top of the line Toshiba tablet (has a great screen, among other things, but not as sharp as the Fire).  In the end, it was price and SOUND that made my decision.  I use my Kindle Fires mostly for music, web and video (aside from reading, of course).  The screen on the 8.9 is absolutely gorgeous!  Yes, the retina dispay on ipad is also fantastic, but the difference was not worth nearly twice the price, IMHO.  But where Kindle blew everyone away was the sound.  The stereo speakers on both sizes cannot be beat.  I literally had to put the speaker of the Toshiba up to my ear to hear it on the loudest setting in the quite noisy store I was in.  A few short steps away, in the same noisy crowd, the Kindle speakers were loud and crystal-clear, and not even all the way up.  I can really crank it up and rarely get any distortion.  Don't worry about the youtube app,etc.  There are plenty of instructions to be found on the net for loading apps like that onto your Kindle Fire.  Took me only a couple of minutes, and the app works just fine.  The silk web browser is fast, and I have no complaints about it.  A word about the ads vs ad-free argument: Unless you reeeeaaallly want to look at a picture of your kids or whatever for the few seconds your lock screen will be seen, I wouldn't bother cancelling the ads.  Even the "suggestions" at the bottom of the carousel are unobtrusive, and don't even show in landscape mode.  It's only $15 to opt out if it really bothers you, but I don't see what all the fuss is about. I used that $15 to buy a magazine subscription to enjoy on my awesome new toy!  I picked up the case made by Amazon, which to me is a must, and will be adding an anti-glare screen protector.  The Fire already has less glare than anything else I looked at, but I still like the protectors. Some things to take into consideration about my review: I do have alot of Amazon content.  Now, I know full well I could still have taken full advantage of my Amazon content from another tablet, but it may make a difference to some of you reading this.  I am not a gamer, and I don't have 500 time-wasting apps on my phone or Kindle, nor do I want them.  And last, I am not and have never been a die-hard Apple fan.  They make great products, but so do other companies.  If you are someone who will not be happy with anything but an ipad, please do yourself a favor and buy one.  Please don't buy this great Kindle Fire HD 8.9 and then return it and post a negative review because it's not an ipad.  I hope my review helps someone!  Thanks for reading.

Reviews.Title: Exactly what was advertised - very satisfied
Reviews.Author: Jeffrey Stanton
Reviews.Content: I ordered the Kindle Fire HD 8.9" from Amazon, along with some accessories, and all I can say, well done Amazon. Everything was delivered on time, well packaged and does exactly what it's suppose to do. This is a Christmas gift for my wife and I couldn't wait until Christmas, so I gave it to her today, the same day I received it. The Kindle Fire HD 8.9 was my choice after doing weeks worth of researching reviews and talking to friends. She absolutely loves it and that means everything to me. Just to see how excited she is as she learns about it is priceless. I have ordered other products from Amazon and have always been satisfied with the product and their service. I am so pleased and impressed with this Kindle and with Amazon. I would recommend both to everyone. Thank you again.

Reviews.Title: Wow
Reviews.Author: E. Henry "Crafty Jean"
Reviews.Content: Although I have a Nook basic book reader, I decided to purchase the Kindle Fire. The HD screen is awesome! It is easy to use by an older semi-techie like myself. I like the carousel of your current/favorite choices. Most of the time it will be used for books or games, but the ability to access other things is great!

Reviews.Title: It All Depends What You Need
Reviews.Author: A. Anderson "ann0314"
Reviews.Content: I have tried out a LOT of different services now , we have iPods (4) and a father with the upper end iPad, we have a cellphone and had a tablet that was Google/Android based, we own a Surface and now we own Kindles (3). Yes I know we jump around a lot LOL. That is because we are trying to find that good balance between features, affordability, longevity, customer service, and ease that meets our needs with the stress on affordability because we are a family of 4 and this technology moves so fast that by the time you buy xyz 3, the new 6 is coming out LOL and keeping up can get VERY pricey on a family budget. My review is about contrasting the differences from my perspective:Customer Service (10/10):In this category for me, Amazon and the Kindle win, hands down. EXCELLENT customer service and I don't mean or take that word lightly at all. I've had to call all 4 companies for things and by FAR Amazon has been the best to deal with. I truly commend them for that in a time where it seems that area lacks more and more.Stability and Speed (7/10):Here I think the iPad/iPods/iPhones win it. Having used all the varying systems by far I think the iPads are the most stable and quick. That said, since the other companies are playing catchup, I would expect that to be so. The Kindle to me falls not terribly behind though. It does freeze here and there and I have had to do a shutdown/restart on occasion, more then with the iPods/iPad, but it isn't to the frequency that I have had to with other products so for me it isn't far off pace.Ease of Use/Base System Features (6.5/10):If you are coming from an iWhatever, you are probably going to come up a bit irritated and possibly baffled and very well may not initially like the Kindle. I know initially when we got ours I was "underwhelmed" especially with how things are setup. In this aspect I think iPads and Android systems have a leg up especially if you are like me and are a bit of an organizational freak. There are NO folders here, no way to move around or order things "your way". To me this was probably the BIGGEST issue I had with the Kindle. If you are someone new to tablets and this is your first, I think the Kindle is pretty straight forward and easy enough to figure out quickly. I know my 11 year old was off and running with it almost instantly."Fun" Applications (9/10):In this area the Kindle is right in line with the rest. For a kid actually BETTER then the other three in terms of Parental Controls and services geared to keep your kids happy without the worry of your child using your credit card accidentally purchase to purchase something (though I will say I have less experience with this feature in the iPads so am speaking more about the Google and Microsoft systems for handling this which are both not so hot especially if you are a family with kids and adults using the same account or wishing to. On the application front, the worst of the bunch is the Surface which has a lot of NOTHING at the moment :( It is new so somewhat expected but I wasn't prepared for quite how anemic their selection really is. Probably one of the largest areas where the Surface falls very flat.Productivity (7/10):If you are looking for a tablet to Browse the net, I think iPad wins it. The Kindles and Android based tablets do well though for the casual user but for a power user you may find the Kindle a bit laggy. If you are looking for something to check e-mail the iPad, Androids, and Kindle all do well. The Surface though has a HUGE issue there. You have to use internet apps to check your e-mail if you have pop3 accounts...REALLY? O.o LOL If you are wanting to use MS Office products the the Surface wins. The rest do have apps that "work" but they do fall short in some areas so you wanna research if you choose this or one of the others to be sure there is something that does what you need. I will say if looking for something more for "school" for a child, the Surface, iPad, or Android tablets that run higher may be better. This system is good for general things listed above but not necessarily strong if you are looking for it to be a laptop replacement for heavy typing and taking notes etc. Great though for browsing forums, getting e-mail, internet, and light work.Reading (10/10):This is handled pretty well across the board with the availability of the Kindle app on most everything these days, though being able to borrow books if you are a Prime Member once a month or being able to restrict what your kids are reading is handled best by using the Physical Kindle.Movies, Music, and Sound (10/10):Strangely enough, the Kindle won on this level for me for a couple reasons (the Surface takes a good second because of the ability to add SD and flash cards to expand its size as do some of the Android systems) Amazon, unknown to me, has "tablet" editions of their movies...I LOVE THIS. If I buy a movie, Amazon gives you a full res version and a mobile version. If you DL the mobile version and put it on the tablet it takes up about 1/2 the space as the same movie on the other systems which means you can put double the movies on it. You do lose some resolution but if it's to keep kids busy on a long car ride its WONDERFUL. If you are more into the quality and want the HD etc though that is there still as an option as well. I also liked the Amazon Prime aspect in this area as well, giving access to lots of movies with your membership. Granted on this Kindle remember you have to have wifi to use Prime. On the music and sound side, I found the speakers on my Kindle to be by FAR the best of the group. The sound is actually REALLY nice. I have to admit I was impressed.Affordability (10/10):Definitely between the Kindles and the Google/Android units I think. For what you are getting for the price I think both these systems are doing a nice job. The iPad is great but not necessarily affordable for the average person especially when you consider what you have now will be outdated in a year or so (if you are lucky) if money is an issue, I would definitely consider these two systems though I won't say the Surface or iPads are unreasonable for what they do, just with their added features etc also have added cost. What that is worth to you really is a personal thing though :)To close (thank heavens right) after getting past the initial shock of how different this system was to the other 3 (especially the Apple system which OS wise I personally like most), I have really enjoyed it and would most definitely recommend it though whether it is best for you really does depend (as you can see above) what it is you are looking for. Fun, Affordability, For a Child, Productivity, Work etc. But for a general use Tablet for a child, reading, browsing the net without a laptop in your lap, I think this tablet definitely does it's job and very very nicely :) My whole family was happy with this purchase and I have recommended it to quite a few friends etc now especially those with kids or looking for an inexpensive solution to the Tablet quest.

Reviews.Title: I love my Kindle
Reviews.Author: Krystal
Reviews.Content: I'll be truthful, I love my Kindle.  I'm new to the tablet world and find it so easy to walk around and do anything i want with my Kindle in hand.  It gives me a whole new view on apps, reading books, watching movies (especially since i have Prime!) and looking at images.As I said, in love, however there are a few things that make me wonder why they didn't catch some bugs before shipping these out to customers.  They are the following:* The Web seems to never be able to successfully open a Webpage the first time when clicking through from an app.  It never fails to ask if i want to reopen my tab because the Web failed at opening it the first time.* My "Photo" option to take photos seems to always freeze.  It will then disable me from taking a photo.* I seem to have to "touch" on something more than once for it to decide to open.I have had my kindle for only 10 days, I think its a great tablet, but think it also could be improved.

Reviews.Title: The Kindle Audio Book Experience
Reviews.Author: Mylrea Estell "Lush Vineyard"
Reviews.Content: I received my Kindle Fire HD 8.9", Dolby Audio, Dual-Band Wi-Fi, 32 GB - Includes Special Offers about two weeks ago. There are plenty of reviews about the overall conformation and performance of the Kindle tablets, but very little about the audio book and Whispersync experience.  Amazon has a selection of free classic books for Kindle, each of which has a companion narration, also free, available from Audible. These are an excellent selection of performances by well know narrators, three of which I had previously purchased myself. I highly recommend new Kindle owners "buy" these free titles and their companion audios.  Whispersync works in multiple ways across multiple devises. I can read or listen to a book on my Kindle, then pick up where I left off, reading or listening using the Kindle app on my Android phone. I especially like the immersive reading function, where the text on the screen is subtly highlighted and "turns the page" following the simultaneous narration.  The immersive reading does not work with books borrowed from The Amazon Prime lending library or with Audible narrations and Kindle books borrowed from the public library, but is very effective when using purchased Kindle books. Audible titles are often deeply discounted when the Kindle book is purchased FIRST. Unfortunately if I want Kindle books to mate to my hundreds of previously purchased audio books, they must be bought at full price. Not a big deal for me as I mostly listen on the go, but no early-adopter wants to feel that they have missed out due to their patronage.  My sole disappointment in the devise has been with the speaker volume, particularly with regard to audio books. I find the maximum volume to be adequate for steaming video from Netflix or Amazon Prime video, but for some reason the audio books are much lower in volume, too quiet for my middle aged ears, even when the Kindle is set on full volume. The speaker capacity is clearly there, and the audiobook volume is fine when I use earphones with my MP3 player, phone or the Kindle, but I can barely hear audio books on the external speakers when holding my Kindle while alone in a quiet room.  My mother has macular degeneration, and audio books are important to her. I had hoped that she could use my Kindle, and the clear controls on its bright screen to access the library of Audible titles I have acquired. She simply could not hear the narrations. Of course she could use headphones, and I am considering Bluetooth speakers, but these extraneous devises are needlessly complex for an elderly person.  I wonder if a software update might allow higher volume audio book playback?  I would also like to see an Overdrive app for the Kindle so that I can use audio books from my state library system. I listen to about 100 audio books a year, most of them free from the library. That does not keep me from being a good Amazon/Audible customer. I have subscribed to Audible's one or two book credits per month program for nearly four years, and have bought more books at the reduced member rate. As long as I'm unable to use my Kindle to download library audio books, I need to use a parallel set of devises for most of my listening. I look forward to software which would allow me to integrate all of my reading and listening.  Since Amazon has purchased Audible and has made great strides to integrate the Kindle reading and listening experience, it is clear that they have identified this as part of the future of reading. Please Amazon programmers do something so that I can set my Kindle down in a room and listen to an audio book as I go about my business.

Reviews.Title: Major bugs never get resolved, quickly loses product software support (no updates).
Reviews.Author: Digitalmaster
Reviews.Content: I can't recommend this product because of the issues that I have had with it the past 4 months that I have owned it.First, when it comes to hardware, I would rate it 3/5. It loses two stars because the power button is on the side, right where the average user holds it to browse the web and play games. Because of the location of the button, it is constantly being depressed, putting it in sleep mode, and having to repeatedly unlock it during a game, or while browsing.The Silk browser is buggy, and I regularly have problems with it crashing. In all fairness, it could be the onscreen keyboard, as most all of my problems happen when the keyboard dialog comes up. Regardless, it makes this unusable for most things that I actually use this for.It is good for videos, and as an Amazon Prime subscriber, it is a great unit, but it spends more time on my shelf due to the issues mentioned above.It's a shame, because I really wanted to love this unit, and less than a month after purchasing, it was replaced with a new unit addressing some of the physical button problems that I mentioned above; problems Amazon told me that they had not heard from other customers... Despite the fact that they addressed the problem in the new version.As a regular Amazon customer, that is using their cloud service, prime, and owns a few Kindle's, this was my most disappointing purchase.

Reviews.Title: Not perfect, but still a great device
Reviews.Author: A. Rosario
Reviews.Content: I was debating between a Nexus 10 and the Kindle Fire HD.  Both devices have their advantages and disadvantages.The Nexus has the Google Play Store along with all of its apps, but you cannot access things such as Amazon Prime without using the browser.  Also, getting a Nexus 10 requires you to work with Google Play Store support which is not always the greatest as I have had to deal with and still am on an issue regarding a music purchase.The Kindle does not have access to the Google Play Store, but it does have the Amazon Appstore as well as Amazon Prime access.  The Amazon Appstore has most of the apps the Google Play Store has including Netflix and many of the games.  The biggest gripe I have with the Kindle is that for some reason Amazon does not offer any of the official Google apps such as Gmail, GTalk, Google Maps and Google Music.  There is a work around to get these apps on the device as I have installed them myself.  You have to authorize installation of 3rd party apps on the device and download the .apk file from a trusted website.  There are numerous websites out there that have official Google apps all you have to do is search for the .apk for the specific app.  Unfortunately, there is no support for the apps this way so you do not get updates and many times the icon looks blurry and not HD on the Kindle carousel.  Other than that, the Kindle is a great device especially when combined with Amazon Prime.  I am using a stylus with it now and find it works better with it.  The WIFI antennas are very good for the device and can connect to very weak signals with ease, would not recommend connecting to just any network as there are hackers out there looking to phish for anything.Amazon Prime is great as it not only grants you access to the numerous TV shows and movies Amazon has under contract, but it allows to borrow books for free from Amazon.As far as the price with the offers goes, I opted to include the offers as it knocked $15 off the price and the offers are only on the device when it is locked.  Upon waking the device (pressing the power button) an offer is displayed.  You swipe to unlock the device and the offer is gone, not to be seen again until you press the power button again once the device is off.  It is not bothersome at all.  I have not had any problems with the offers thing and at times I have been interested by the offers.I opted for the Kindle, purchased December of 2012, as it was cheaper and it allowed me to access Amazon Prime shows with no problem.  I also liked the Kindle reading aspect of it.  The device does have a setting under reading font, Sepia, which makes it so much easier to read than a regular white screen.  This is actually on any device that you download the Kindle app for including cell phones.I would recommend this device to anyone looking for a tablet that allows for a lot of media consumption as it has access to Amazon Prime with ease as well as Netflix.  In addition, it would be a better device for families as it allows parents to lock parts of the device to prevent children from purchasing or accessing things they are not supposed to.

Reviews.Title: This is by far the best tablet out there for the price!
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "Kevin Hearn"
Reviews.Content: Let me just start off by saying that I am not an apple fanboy, so I have never truly been impressed with iPads or any other Apple product after 2000. I don't feel like the value is there, and as someone who doesn't have a ton of cash to drop on something like a tablet, I just can't justify spending minimum $500-800 on one.I have had my Kindle Fire HD 8.9" tablet (32 GB) since they first came out in November and all I can say is: WOW! These tablets are amazing! I can tell you that it has literally changed my life (in a good way). :) I am going to list my comments individually in sections so y'all can see the parts that are most applicable to you.Build quality:I like the very solid, ergonomic feel of this Kindle. It is light enough to hold in one hand comfortably, yet I never feel like I'm going to drop it due to its weight (unlike my Galaxy S2 Smartphone). I do not, however, like the buttons on the top that control volume and the on/off. These buttons are almost completely flush to the device and it can be very difficult to press them. I also continually press the wrong button on the volume rocker to change the volume on the device because it feels backwards to me. I also wish the device could know when I changed it from landscape to portrait and adjust the volume knob to be a little more intuitive that way. That may sound like nitpicking, but it can be an annoyance.Screen:On that note, the screen on this thing is just gorgeous. I have used it outside, inside, full light, no light, everywhere you can imagine and I have never had a problem seeing anything on the device anywhere. I live in South Texas and it can be quite bright here in the daytime (especially around noon-2pm) and I have spent many Saturdays outside reading my Kindle without any problems. It does require more brightness out of the screen which reduces battery life, but I never read outside for more than two or three hours so I have never had an issue with running out of power. I cannot say enough positive things about this screen!User Interface:I love the Amazon Silk browser, it is great and works seamless with almost everything. I did the infamous flash workaround with the dolphin browser (google it) and that works great as well. The only complaint I have about the apps is...sometimes I don't want apps to come onto the carousel after I use them. I am major OCD and I like to have my carousel totally empty besides the book that I am reading. I like the apps and I use them often, but I have to remove them from the carousel periodically. I wish there was an option that said "do not put apps on carousel", or even a list of apps you could put on the device that would do the same. Again, nitpicky....but a tad bit annoying.Reading:What can I say about the reading on this device? It is superb. From magazines, to books, to newspapers...everything is great. I have never had a problem with any of this and it works great. I love getting my Men's Fitness and my fiance loves getting Cosmo as well. They are always crisp and clear (gotta love that HD screen) and are never glitchy or freezing. This is really where this Kindle has changed my life. I am a teacher and it is very difficult for me to fit certain books into my backpack for school...but it is easy to fit my Kindle in there. I have read more books in the past five months of owning this thing than I had in a year.Ordering:Part of the reason I have had so much success with my reading is that it is very easy to order books from the device. I have bought books and had family members buy me books for my birthday and never had a problem. It is almost TOO easy to buy things for this device...because I spend a lot of money on books to read every month. Again, no complaints. It is far easier to make a buy on my device (which I keep with me perpetually) instead of having to remember to hit up a bookstore on the way home. And, let me add, cheaper to buy on the Kindle.Videos:I bought extra storage space to put my DVR shows on my Kindle for watching at various points when I am not home. Besides the fact that the only content it plays is .MP4 (a tad annoying) but the videos are always crisp and clear and never have to buffer or queue. I have absolutely zero complaints about video or playback on the device.Overall I would say that I have absolutely zero regrets with my Kindle. I have nitpicky concerns, but they are far outweighed by the benefits of this device. If you are like me and looking for something to make reading books and magazines easier-or even watching videos or movies, this is definitely the Kindle for you. I hope this review helps any of you that are on the fence about buying a Kindle Fire HD 8.9". I love it so much, in fact, my fiance is getting one for her birthday, so she stops stealing mine. :)

Reviews.Title: My third version of the kindle
Reviews.Author: W. Dietrich "WD"
Reviews.Content: I have had all 3 versions of the kindle from the original which was just a reader with no color ink (which i really enjoyed) to the 2011 kindle fire to the new Kindle Fird HD 8.9.I am giving the 8.9 4 stars for one reason when I flip the kindle sideways when reading a book I get two pages at once instead of one page which is what I get if I am holding the kindle up right.  There may be a way to fix this but I am not sure how.  They say the new Kindle Fire HD has a sharper picture than the original Kindle Fire but for my eyesight I can not tell the difference.  What I do like is the size is awsome and makes playing games like angry birds or fruit ninja even better.  The backlight for reading makes reading with the lights off a breeze (does not hurt my eyes at all).  I love that amzon imported my music onto my kindle / cloud and the sound is very crisp when I use my earphones its like listiening to my MP3.  I also thought it was easy to bring over my photos from facebook to my kindle so I can share them with friends. However there are times when I am using my kindle that my hand will accedintaly hit the off button and I need to restart the kindle which is easy but still a drag this happens to me at least twice a day (i use the kindle for several hours daily).  Also, for what you pay it would nice to be receive a wall charger instead of the usb plug.  I paid extra for the rapid charger and did not notice much of a difference in charging time from my normal phone charger that has the same size charger.  All in all I love the kindel the ease it provides in shopping amazon, the ability to play my music, the importing of photos and most of all the ability to read with the lights off.  I dont like the fact that I often shut down the kindle by accident, the fact it did not have a wall charger and that when you hold sideways you get two pages instead of one.

Reviews.Title: Best kindle yet!
Reviews.Author: Staci B
Reviews.Content: I have had 3 different Kindles (the 6inch wireless reading device, the Kindle fire and now the Fire HD 8.9inch) and they get better each time! I have not had any problems with them each time I have had to replace them it has been due to theft or one got broken in a car accident. So happy to have a new one with the bigger screen and such high quality speakers. The images on the screen are so colorful and bright. Thought about getting an iPad but glad that I stayed with the Kindle brand! I love the Prime membership and being able to borrow books and movies! That is so wonderful. I do wish you could play games without being on wifi, but I understand that most of them have ads that make it able to be free apps and they need wifi to be able to run those ads. That is really my only complaint, for the most part I read so it works wonderfully.

Reviews.Title: Good but a work in progress.
Reviews.Author: Dairenn Lombard
Reviews.Content: I've owned the Kindle Fire HD 8.9 for 24 hours now, and I have a number of impressions I'd like to share already.  But first, I wanted to talk about why I bought it.  Whipping out a heavy, hot laptop with that classic anemic battery power, under-powered graphics and sound for a thousand dollars, give or take four hundred bucks, was an unattractive proposition.  When I want to watch a video in bed, on the plane or in a waiting room, a tablet is perfect.  We're living in a tablet world now, so unlike when the iPad was the only game in town, now there's this thing, the Nexus 7 and even the Nexus 10.  Here's why I chose the Kindle Fire...  First, I already own a Kindle (e-ink Keyboard) and it ROCKS; light weight, long battery life, beautiful display, easy to use, wonderfully simple to buy content and enjoy it in mere seconds; a beautiful product.  A coworker showed me their Kindle Fire and it was also gorgeous, and this is a gorgeous product.  Easily competes with the iPad in the looks department.  As the advertising says, its display is visually indistinguishable from that of the Retina display on my wife's iPad.  I've been shopping for content from Amazon for years and I've been a Prime member for a while now, so getting to watch all my favorite TV shows and movies without dealing with a DVD player or the DVD drive in a crappy laptop is really nice.  It's so nice to be able to jump around--between social media, to movies, to my e-mail, to Skype with my wife when I'm out of town, over to my MP3s in the Amazon cloud.  The IDEA behind this product is awesome.So here's what it gets right...  Looks cool.  Awesome graphics.  Great sound in the headphones.  Based on Android so you can use some Android apps out of the Google Play store or Android MarketPlace in addition to the Amazon App store.  Reasonably priced.  Even though I use my other Kindle for reading, reading on this thing is pretty nice.  Screen is bright, color is deep and rich, very little glare, so, magazines are fun to thumb through on this device.  Some gripes I encountered on YouTube while trying to decide to purchase this thing included hard-to-locate power button.  I don't ever have problems finding and using the power button.  It is lame you have to purchase the power brick, but it does work and it's worth getting.  It's not too big to carry and if you get the cool leather case, you can stand it up for hands-free use.  I don't recommend the screen protector--it's crap (you get this oily looking rainbow coloring that doesn't go away no matter what you look at on the screen).  I don't care about the Special Offers--who is looking at their lock screen long enough to be annoyed by these ads?  Not me.  It doesn't have a rear camera but I already have a camera, AND a camera in my phone.  It's easy enough to transfer either of these things to this device via USB.  The camera it has is good enough for what it was meant for--Skype and video blogging.  The keyboard isn't the best, BUT, I hate all touchscreen keyboards; they're all hard to use.Here are the problems and I really hate saying this, but, there are a lot.  #1, the interface is the least intuitive of any thing I have ever used.  I wish I had at least one physical button that lets me just "go home" no matter where I am, which I think is ironic.  You get *physical* volume up/down buttons, but not a home button.  Instead, if apps hide your home/back/favorites icon bar, you have to remember to tickle the border to see if you can make it show up so you can get out of what you're doing.  Same deal with "settings."  You have to remember to drag down the top border to get to REALLY useful things.  Something like that should be on the home screen, which takes me to my next gripe.  There is no home screen.  I'd like a nice clean "page" that lets me go to my apps, or, content, or whatever, but basically has nothing but the time and maybe a couple of status icons (i.e., On Wi-Fi, notifications from running apps, etc).  Instead, you get the carousel and I'm sorry, but, I don't like this thing, at all.  It's goofy to use and has a mind of its own...  Things go on it whether you want them to or not.  The most recent thing shows up first all the time, which is convenient, since when you swipe to the end of the carousel, there's no way to go back to the beginning unless you use the home icon.  I really hate that it insists on telling you what other people bought as Large icons under the highlighted app in the carousel.  I wish I could uninstall FreeTime; I will never give this to someone who needs an app to tell you when to stop using it.Reviewers complained about laggy performance and it's true.  If this thing gets busy with anything (moving around files, running certain apps), screen rotation, carousel swiping, etc. hangs/freezes for a moment.  I haven't heard much about the parental controls but I have a need to keep certain videos, photos and files password protected without locking the entire unit.  And the bad news is, parental controls are either ON or OFF.  When it's on, you can't just enter a password and access that feature.  All those features are just outright blocked.  So you have to REMEMBER to turn it back on every time you're done with a feature you don't want someone getting into by accident.  Even worse?  You can't do it by app.  You can either block all apps, or enable all apps.  REALLY bad.Storage management is a bit of a mess.  If you move a file from one folder to the other, it makes a Copy first.  So if you're nearly out of space on this device, the operation will fail.  No other computer disk system I've ever used works that way.  I know, no tablet gives you the ability to plugin and eject your own SD cards; which would have been a huge competitive advantage for this device.  Because the internal storage IS and SD card!!  How cool would it be that when you fill up the relatively microscopic 16 or 32 GB internal storage on this thing (because you don't want to have to use your WiFi every time you want to watch a movie), you could just plugin your own whopping 128 GB SD card and keep going?  No instead you have to play three-card-monty with the files on this thing, and the USB on this guy is the slowest of any Flash USB-based storage system I've ever used.  Or, literally double how much you are spending for the 4G version, the only model that offers up to 64 GB internal storage.  I wish the photo viewer organized pictures into folders--especially if that's the way I copied them there from a computer.  No matter what, ALL sort-by-date, ALL sort-by-name or ALL-sort-by-size is almost never how I want to browse my pictures or play them back in a slideshow.  Lastly, USB copy operations seems to use a TON of battery, and that it refuses to charge while plugged into USB (not even at all, not just slowly) is big-time design fail status.The "booming bass with no distortion" is a myth and was a primary reason for me to purchase the device.  The sound is stereo at least, and it is nice and clear.  And, perhaps if I played something with Dolby Digital encoding to activate the codec that might help.  But playing back my own MP3s or YouTube music videos is better off done through nice ear buds (good ones, not the cheap white things Apple gives you with an iPod).  You can't play back the vast majority of major video file formats out there, but, if you download and install MoboPlayer (after enabling application installation from "unknown sources" in settings), you will be in business.  No converting hundreds of files on a computer and then spending hours transferring them over slow USB.  Just transfer them once and play and DOES respect folders.  All hail the power of the Android operating system.I'm hoping that stuff gets better as new versions of the OS come out and I download and upgrade my device to use them although I get the feeling the more annoying things are here to stay...  Carousel is probably their money feature, so if you hate it, that's too bad.  I would say however that if you don't care about all of the stuff I found annoying, then for the money, you're going to get a good product out of this device.  It serves my needs and I didn't have to spend iPad money to get a tablet that lets me watch my videos and look at photos without having to lug around a laptop or be chained to my desk or home TV.

Reviews.Title: This is the bomb!!!
Reviews.Author: KenDiesel
Reviews.Content: Let me write this with all you people out there that have never had a tablet before. I myself would have never purchased one but for that my train magazines were going digital. I did my research. I talked to my brother who had an I-Pad3 and my sisters-in-laws that had kindles and samsung 7inch.  I looked at info and reviews online.  Now by the time I had done all this I was totally confused. All these people bad mouthing the different units vs. the people saying they were absolutely great. I started to note that a lot of the people bad mouthing were nit picking the units to death or were not following the proper procedures of setting up or using the proper cables or items required by the vendor.I finally decided, do I need a tablet is more business and entertainment for a higher price(ipad or samsung) or a unit that is made mostly for entertainment as a less price(Kindle). I pulled the trigger on the Kindle Fire HD 8.9.When I received it the unit felt just right size wise in my hands. (The Ipad that I tried was a little larger and the Samsung 7 inch felt and looked small, the 10" to large). I hooked up to my wifi within 2 minutes. I started looking around and figured out how to download a free book(I signed up for Amazon prime-great deal for $79 a year) on the Kindle and started looking up all the things I could do. Within a week I was almost a pro. The movies that I have downloaded are just spectacular. Graphics of 1920 x 1200 are detailed. Amazon has a lot of apps, games, magazines, tunes and about anything else you could want. It so bad, I have limited myself to 1 hour a day using this tablet.Now, you may be saying this person doesn't know much about the specifics of all the things that are needed to be done and the Kindle can't do it. But, for the average person like me.  This is the bomb!!!I would recommend anyone out there that wants a tablet for reading, playing games, using apps and movies. Look no farther.  As Goldilocks said with the 3 bears, "This one is just right".  I hoped this average person had helped you on your search for a tablet.

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire HD 8.9" is a wonderful product
Reviews.Author: J. A. Shanholtz
Reviews.Content: After much research I finally decided that I was going to upgrade from my Kindle Keyboard to a Kindle Fire.  When I researched and reviewed all the specs and reviews on all of the Kindles, I finally decided on the Kindle Fire HD 8.9 16 GB Wi-Fi.  Like so many others in the reviews, I was undecided as to whether or not I should get the 32GB and the 4G version or the Wi-Fi 16 GB.  So I read the reviews and then I really looked specifically at what I would be using it for, where I would be using it, what size would work best for my needs, and at the price, all of which really helped me make my decision.  The Kindle Fire HD 8.9" is a little bigger and that works better for my eyes, especially for reading.  I am an avid book reader and loved my first Kindle but the Kindle Fire HD 8.9" is truly a huge improvement and a beautiful little tablet.  The quality and size are great for the price.  The HD is better than most TV's, the sound is great, the graphics are fabulous, and it's easy to use and go back and forth between functions.  I use it mostly at home or places where I can use safe Wi-Fi .  I really didn't want to add another bill for a data plan, so this Kindle works great for me.  I have mostly books on it, some music, several apps, and a couple of videos, so the 16 GB is good enough for my needs.  I also like that I can read email and send documents to it to use for my work, if I need to in a pinch.  I also purchased the Kindle Leather Cover in Royal Purple which is beautiful and the Kindle Powerfast Accelerated Charger, which I also got both at a discount when I purchased my Kindle.  I am very happy that I got the charger because it does charge it much faster.  This is probably the con that I would say that I have with the  Kindle Fire HD 8.9"  Wi-Fi 16GB.  I think it should have come with the wall charger like it did with my other Kindle, but it doesn't keep me from giving this Kindle 5 stars.  It's a wonderful product for the price and I am very, very happy that I chose to upgrade to this Kindle.  I also received my purchases in one package before the date that they were expected to arrive.  I buy so much from Amazon and I can honestly say that I have never been disappointed with their service or products.  I would highly recommend to anyone looking for a great and easy to use tablet at a reasonable price, to buy a Kindle Fire HD in the size and style that fits their needs. It's a wonderful product!

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire HD
Reviews.Author: Donald J. Dennison "When there is nothing lef...
Reviews.Content: 1st off Im an Amazon guy. Buy stuff here all the time. used to have the kindle fire when it first came out(same day)  I am also an Ipad guy. At least since the Ipad 2.  So to me there will be comparisons. i sold my kindle fire because the screen was just too small for me. So when the new 8.9 came out I was really happy and also got it right away.1st off. Im very happy with the way it feels in my hands. I hadn't bought a case for it as I wanted to see it 1st. Definatly needs a case as it feels like it might break in your hands being so thin. I turned it on, it knew me already and loaded its software  so far so good.I love the picture quality, perhaps even better then the Ipad (I have the Ipad4)Silk is ok no complaints as a browser except what I wrote below. Sound is better then the IpadI do have issues with it though... ill get into thoseSPEED...It claims its over %40 faster then new ipad  ofcourse they dont tell you which generation of ipad they are talking about. The ipad 2 was called new ipad as well as the 3 and 4i have the 4 and it is not close to as fast as my ipad 4  i would compare the speed to the 3rd generation Ipad but it loses to the 4thi did side by side comparisons as the ipad won even if I clicked 1st on the kindleIm not saying its slow, its not.  its just not as fast as the ipad 4SCREEN...I would have to say the kindle is just a bit sharper then the ipad 4Sound...not even close Kindle winsAPPS...Not even close Apple wins that onebut thats not to say there isnt a good selection to choose from. Personally i feel android needs to catch up with the apsWEB BROWSING...Hard to say here i have no issues browsing on the ipad 4 however any pages with flash dont work or load funnyKindle handles those pages without a problem however i get so frustrated at the kindle when web browsing. Its a bit hard to explain, the response time isnt as good and sometimes i have to touch the spot 4 or 5 times like to go back, click on a link etc...ipad wins on ease of use but the kindles isnt really that bad here i call it a draw as I would rather have the flash loadTYPING...The ipad wins buy a landslide for me. you can tell apple is into ease of use, the kindles typing is klunky and I possible would not have purchased it had I realised how bad it is for me. If I make a mistake a few words back it is almost imposible to get to it to edit.  Lucky for me i only type in emails and its not that big of a deal for me. If i had to rely on typing i would not want the kindleSo with all this, the kindle is a much better price. And frankly I havent used my Ipad 4 at all since getting my kindle HDim still getting used to it, with the price and sound its worth itboth the ipad and kindle have things that are better then the otherthats just my 2 cents  hope it helps someone

Reviews.Title: Just what we wanted
Reviews.Author: Shaun I. Thomasarnold
Reviews.Content: This is a great device, the bigger screen makes a big difference and it has everything my wife could want in terms of features.From facebook to her shows on HBO Go, this has everything she would use on a laptop and for less cost and with easier portability and use. Plus no data plan to worry about like the ipad.Having an e-reader is great, it streamlines the library and puts everything right there. My wife has a couple different books she is reading, plus her reading for her women's church group, plus her bible. So having it all conveniently in one device makes it a lot easier than carrying those all around.The only gripe I have is the lack of a good usage guide for simple things, like setting up the calender schedule/planner or simply highlighting text. Most of this can easily be found with a quick google, but it would still be nice to have some info included.All in all, an awesome device and cheaper than an ipad or laptop. Definitely going to get our money's worth out of this one.

Reviews.Title: Why I love it In 1,600 words (a novice review)
Reviews.Author: Mr. King-Shaw
Reviews.Content: This review is written after having the Kindle Fire 8.9 for less than a week.  This is my first tablet; I still don’t own a SmartPhone (I still carry an original Razr).  I was considering this against the iPad mini after doing some personal research online and with friends primarily.  My first Kindle (the only other one in the house actually) is the keyboard version (before the PaperWhite model) and I’ve used laptops for…who knows how many years.  Also this review is written for the tablet novice in mind; those who are experts on the subject have had quite a bit to say about the Fire HD.  I please ask you to keep these facts in mind as you read the review.Personally, I love this thing.  There are a few detractions which I’ll get into later, but they mostly hinge on the lack of charger and lack of a backward facing camera.The first item I’ll get into is the ads.  I purchased the 16GB version with ads and let me say this:  they are unobtrusive and non-intrusive.  They appear on the lock screen, so you see it once the Fire awakens, and when you look at items on your carousel (books, apps and games) there is a small banner that shows what others who have that app/book have purchased.  For those who complain about these ads, I recognize that we all have an opinion and I’m not going to invalidate them.  However if you have watched TV (like CBS, ESPN or CNN) or read a magazine (Like Time, Automobile and others) or been to any website outside of your own private network then you’re already used to commercials & ads…especially in a magazine.  This is far less intrusive than what you find in a magazine and far less prevalent than commercials.  For $15 off the price I think it’s a great deal.  I would say that people should not be concerned with ads on your Kindle Fire HD; you’re on this website & you’re looking at ads already.Next, getting into how I’ve used this thing every day.E-Reader:  It’s great, however just like any other tablet, you have a backlight.  Personally I find the e-ink on a normal Kindle easier on the eyes and if *all* you’re going to do is read e-books, I’d suggest going the route of a PapwerWhite or standard Kindle.  On here you can choose a traditional black on white print, sepia (to simulate a slightly yellowed book) or white on black for reading material.  This setting translates across anything you read on your Fire HD (I have a magazine subscription and a double-tap of articles breaks out the article into the black/white I’ve selected).  Your books synchronize across your devices, just like any other kindle/kindle reading app.However chances are if you’re reading this you were going to do more than just read e-books.  Let’s get into it, but only reviewing what the Fire HD comes with & what you can get on the Amazon Android App store.  I have not ‘sideloaded’ anything to my Fire; everything I have on my Fire is from the Amazon App store.Video:  My goodness this thing rocks.  You can use the instant watch (tons of things are free for Prime members) and you can use a USB to put your personal videos on your Fire.  Additionally you can grab several free apps such as Netflix or Xfiniti to allow you to stream video to your Fire.  The display is crisp and awesome.  You may consider getting an app or two for some video formats.  I know I can watch MP4 video on my Kindle; AVI is not natively supported.  As mentioned there are several apps that can remedy that situation.Related – Sound:  I’m a bit of a sound snob.  Short of headphones, this is the best sound I’ve heard from a mobile device by a wide margin, including my HP laptop with BeatsAudio.  It’s not just crisp, it’s true stereo, and dynamic at that.  Now it doesn’t give you surround sound the way a nice set of headphones will give you, but if there’s *equal* sound on any tablet out there I’d like to know.  Example, I watched a video on YouTube that I’d watched before and for the first time I could tell that some voices from the crowd were from the right, with others in the left & middle.  Speaking of which this leads me to…Web Surfing.  This comes with Silk, the browser from Amazon.  Fact: there is no flash support.  Fact: I can watch YouTube vids just fine.  I suspect it may have to do with if the video has HD available.  The browser is fast and stable, most of the time.  There have been a few pages that have hung up on me, forcing a close.  I’ve found this is more of a site-specific item rather than Silk in general.  FaceBook had a couple issues when I went to the Washington DC Auto Show and used the free WiFi in the convention center.  I downloaded the FB app later that day and FB worked fine from the house; when I returned to the Auto Show the next day & had good WiFi the app and surfing worked just fine.Apps.  The Amazon Android App store has a ton of content, and it’s really easy to get to.  Plus you can just click another included app to shop the regular Amazon store; easy as pie.  It’s not like you only have five apps to choose from.  However out of the box while you can view documents (word, PDF, excel) you cannot edit them.  There are apps that can be purchased that will allow you to do this, but it’s still something I would have preferred.  That said there are enough things to get you up & running.Documents – taking a second here to write a quick note about documents on the Fire HD.  Yes, you can read them (.docx, .xlsx, etc.) but you cannot edit them with the supplied software.  Personally I find that when I want to edit items I use a laptop, but if you’re expecting to be able to edit a spreadsheet you’ll need an app from the store.Battery Life.  Nice and solid; they claim 10 hours of constant use and I believe them.  I used mine all day at the show, then continued to use it at home.  Plug it in at night and you’re good to go the next day.  If you want to make that charge last longer, turn the Fire off rather than use the sleep function.The great surprise was what has become my favorite feature.  E-mail.Sounds like a simple thing, but the e-mail client that comes with the Fire HD 8.9 allows you to view all your e-mail in a single app.  If you have a few different e-mail addresses this thing is a life saver!  I have two g-mail, two yahoo and a home account on this device; you can even set it up for an exchange (work) e-mail client.  This has made it incredibly easy to keep up on all my addresses, including information from friends!  Each one has a dedicated folder, but you can also view them all in one folder should you choose.  Had you told me two weeks before writing this that I’d rave about the e-mail more than anything else I would have laughed in your face.If you’ve never owned a tablet before, this one is GREAT.  It has the Amazon store loaded right up onto it, you can get great apps for android tablets, video & sound are better than anything I’ve been exposed to and the price is much better than the i-pad.  That’s not to say this thing isn’t perfect however.  Here are a couple things to consider.First, it does *not* come with a wall charger, and that’s a shame.  You can plug it into the USB port in your computer but that is one slow charge.  They offer a wall charger for twenty bucks extra.  If you have one of the USB wall plug in chargers – specifically if it reads 9 or 10 amps, you’re good to go.Next, they only have a single camera…pointed right at you.  While that’s great for Skype (comes on the Fire) it’s not great for taking pictures of anything other than yourself.  Yes, you can make the camera work with some agility (you just can’t get a good look at what you’re taking a picture of) but that’s a big minus in my book.  As a result of this layout, any app for taking pictures or video is in my opinion…rather worthless.The last part of my review is to explain why I (personally) felt this was better than getting an i-pad mini.For thirty bucks less I get a larger display, a *better* display (larger is not always better!) and I can share my books/music with my other devices.  On top of that there’s the sound that’s awesome in comparison.  Apple makes a nice product.  I personally feel this is a better oneI thought about getting the Fire 7 inch but opted for the larger display to view video & photos on a nicer display, but I have to admit I considered saving the extra $100 and spending it on apps or (more likely) gas.Pick up a case and a screen protector.  If you’re a first time tablet owner, you’ll be using this thing quite a lot.And you’ll be happy you did.That’s my review in 1,600 words.

Reviews.Title: Goodbye iPad
Reviews.Author: Gandalfe
Reviews.Content: Luv'd my iPad, but love the Kindle much more. No more dealing with iTunes, so much free stuff. And my music and book just magically appear on the device. I really like this tablet.

Reviews.Title: One Hot Tablet... Best for Price
Reviews.Author: WaJA Ink In Hand
Reviews.Content: Prior to my purchasing the Kindle Fire HD 8.9" 16G Wi-fi, like most of you, I did a lot of online comparing.  I had always been an iPad user.  Yet, because my iPad was a 1st Generation model, it had already begun to lag behind it's newer relatives in terms of newer features and updates.  So, since they are really very expensive IMO, I went into the hunt for a future tablet willing to purchase something else. After all, there are a lot of really good tablets out there right now.  So after doing a lot of reading and looking at tablets in stores, My thinking kind of went like this.I liked the Nexus 10 over the iPad, and by a little bit over the Kindle Fire HD 8.9", even though it was close. What got me was the Nexus 10 has a resolution of 2560 x 1600  at 300 ppi.  Now having said that about the hardware, my eyes really liked the Nexus 10 and the Kindle Fire HD for two different reasons (from what i could see on the internet).  When I looked at the Nexus 10, I said, "Wow, that is just overall great looking!  Great uniformity. No lag.  Awesome looking movies, etc.  And when I looked at the KFHD, I again said, "Wow!"  The flesh tones are awesome.  And whoa! The colors pop on this device. So, I read some more online reviews.  And people were saying the same thing about the KFHD.  And yes, The iPad looked great, just like always. But, I concluded, I really didn't want an iPad anymore. I really wanted something else. I love Apple's computers, but.. their tablets? Hmm? I've seen what other people have and there is some pretty nice stuff out there.  So, I liked  the Nexus 10, because of what I knew about the High Resolution numbers, and not so much by what I could see! And I liked the colors and the overall picture of the KFHD.Then, I started to evaluate the tablets in terms of what they could do. And I determined that the Nexus 10 is a BEAST.  It does most everything really well. And it has apps galore from the Google Play Store.  It flat out gets the job done.  It has a front and rear camera.  Movies look fantastic on it.  When scrolling from App Screen to App Screen, it doesn't stick or lag.  It is solid! BUT... BUT... It is also $100 more than the KFHD.. OUCH! And that is not really so good!On the other hand, the Kindle Fire is one HOT TABLET! Why? Because of what it does so WELL! it is designed to buy, rent, borrow,  and use products from Amazon online.  And whoa! What it does it does really really well. Movies, Pictures, games, comics, books, you name it, The KFHD is designed to QUICKLY and easily bring all that Amazon experience to you efficiently and cleanly! The KFHD's visual experience is FANTASTIC in its display of the product in action.  And it sounds excellent in terms of it's audio presentation.  It will absorb you, as it interacts with you.  At least, it did for me!  And as I was absorbed people yelled at me. It seems time flew by with out me.  It's a great experience. Well.. err.. yeahNow, I am going to admit something to all of you.  At first, I almost sent my Kindle back.  After coming away from an iPad experience, it was really hard at first for me to get used to the difference.  I just couldn't get the KFHD to do what I wanted.  For example, I was looking for the "same" Apps in the Amazon store, as I had on  the iPad that I had just sold.  For the most part, I couldn't find them.  Well, after I changed my kindle settings to allow for downloading from outside sources, this began to change.  Eventually I found most of what I had on my iPad on the web, and I downloaded those Apps to my Kindle.  Then I found substitutes from the Amazon Store for the things I could not on the net.  As I started to use the tablet after that, I really started to love my device.  And the more I used it, the more I liked it!  Now, I'm so glad that I purchased this.  It does everything that I want it too, and more than I imagined it could.I have to say, the Home Screens categories are spot on for what they offer.  Comics, Books, Apps, movies, games, etc., it's all here, and easily accessible.  I don't have to click on this, and then click on that.. oh yeah, and then click on this, just to get what i really want. It's all right there in each of those categories at the top of the Home Screen. And to top it off, Amazon Prime is such a great idea! My goodness, free two day shipping for prime members from Amazon? Are you kidding me? That's great!One more thing here really quickly.  I understand where a lot of people are coming from with their not liking the Ads showing up on their Kindle HD's.  Here is kind of the way I look at it.  When I browse the intent, nearly every webpage has ads on it. When I used apps on my Apple iPad, a good many of them had ads on them. The same is true of my phones apps.  IMO we live in a culture that likes to sell things. And one of the easiest ways do do that, is through Ads.  Now, I can't remove every single ad from my browser.  I can't remove every single ad from all of my apps on each of my devices.  BUT, I can remove the ads on my Kindle Fire HD.  I will have to pay $15.00 to do so.  BUT at least it is AN OPTION.  Now, I'm not so sure that I will do that.  The Ads on the lock screen look fantastic on the KFHD. And there just might be something there that I might buy. Anyway I don't know, if I'll remove them or not.Now, I'd like to make one recommendation to the people at AMAZON.  Would it be possible to provide some options to customers like me, that get bored looking at the same screen every time I use my device. For example, you could allow users to CUSTOMIZE the home screen.  The Home Screen lists at the top of the screen: Shop, Games, Apps, Books, Music, Videos, Newsstand, Audiobooks, Web, Photos, Docs & Offers. Why not let us decide which one of titles and their contents is going to be our Home Screen.  And I think it would be great if  Carousel was an option too.  And, what about a little color, huh? Could you also allow for some back ground color on the Home Screen?  I love my KFHD.  BUT, I must admit, having to look at the black background constantly gets a little OLD.  A little customization might help to make the kindle feel a little more like it's the owners and not just some interface that AMAZON is using.Anyway... To sum up... In terms of Quality for the Price, I think the KFHD is an absolute winner.  I really like the Nexus 10 too, BUT, it is $100 more than I can afford right now. Is the Nexus worth what people are paying for it? Well, maybe not right now.. because I see some of them selling for over $100  the advertised price, since they are sold out on the Google site, and people want them so badly for Christmas. I think it's getting a little out of hand.  But, for $100 more, which is what it usually sells for? Then it is a toss up! KFHD or Nexus 10?  Bother are great tablets. But in my case: for a $299 starting price, nothing beats my KFHD.  It is ONE HOT TABLET! Best for Price!

Reviews.Title: Love it!!
Reviews.Author: Clifton L. Smith
Reviews.Content: Amazon has created an awesome device in the Kindle Fire HD 8.9. Everything works perfectly. WiFi connects fast. Downloads are super lightening fast! I can't seem to put it down. The display is amazing! Colors pop. Videos and magazines are gorgeous. The device is well-constructed and sturdy. The sound from the speakers is nice and loud with a rich tonal quality. The user interface and software seem mature and polished. I would say that it is highly intuitive to use. Ridiculously easy to use, actually. I had purchased a Nook HD+ a month ago but I returned it. It was such an underwhelming device. Additionally, the software was buggy and the screen often was non-responsive.  I still currently own a Samsung Galaxy Note 10.1 tablet, a Motorola Xoom 10 inch tablet, a Nook Color and Kindle DX. They are all going up for sale soon(except the Kindle DX, that is). The Kindle Fire HD 8.9 makes me not want to pick them up again. Amazon's app and media store is tremendous. If you are looking for the Google experience, then this is not the product for you; as most of the Google apps are not available. Even when side-loaded the Google apps that require account sign-in will not function. Nevertheless, I can manage just fine without the Google experience. To sum up: high-quality device, fantastic hardware, great software, stupendous app and media selection, great price. What more can you ask for in a tablet? Go Amazon!

Reviews.Title: Merry Christmas to ME
Reviews.Author: NancyM "WebAngel"
Reviews.Content: I love it, got it mainly for reading books and the ability to hook it up to my large screen tv.  I'm hoping that this will work for our elderly neighbor who has macular degeneration and a difficult time reading books.  Hooking up to the TV should enable her to pick a larger font and then get back to a pasttime she loves.  As for me, my only complaint is that it can be just a tad "heavy" compared to a smaller screen e-reader that I used to use.  I've arthritis in my fingers and hands.  Having a leather case that allows me to stand it up helps relieve my having to hold it!  Wireless hookup is great and I actually get better reception than I do on my desktop!

Reviews.Title: Still on fire!!!
Reviews.Author: BertG007
Reviews.Content: I received my new Kindle Fire last week and it's exactly what I expected - awesome!The 8.9" is perfectly sized and the HD screen is razor sharp. I purchased the 7" Kindle last year and while a nice unit, here size matters and this Kindle rocks.

Reviews.Title: "Getting To Know You"
Reviews.Author: gagbit "gagbit"
Reviews.Content: I'm a "techie junkie".  But I also want an item that is easy to use, reliable, fast helps (uploads and downloads), and provides a multitude of functions.  I've gone through the transition from PC to laptop to notebook to tablet.  Because I "don't leave home without it" (my tablet) I want it to function just as well as at home (connection reliability, functionality).I recently decided to "go for it", and purchase the Kindle Fire HD 8.9, originally to free up my BB Playbook so I could give it to my Grandson.  I LOVED my Playbook, and was skeptical about the KF meeting my high expectations.  OK, I give....it's everything it's proposed to be, and WELL worth the cost.  The only thing I lost was a massive amount of GB (Playbook = 68GB, Kindle Fire = 16GB).  That's ok.I wondered if ease of use would be there as soon as I unpacked it.  Yup! I have yet to indoctrinate the bookstore/usage, or the movies, but that will happen.Is it an iPad? Of course not.  That's not it's sole purpose. Would I recommend this for those who don't need all the apps and fluff of an iPad at a reasonable cost?  A resounding "YES"!  I did an extensive review and research of the KF HD, and it got high marks for what I wanted it to do, without being tied to a MAC, and feeling my comfort zone with a PC.

Reviews.Title: In a word, the new k-FireHD 8.9" is awesome.
Reviews.Author: Michael Bridges
Reviews.Content: My wife (who is NOT computer skilled) took to it like a fish in water.  I think mostly because she was already comfortable with her android phone.  Everything they said that was good about it is has turned out to be true.  I got the 32GB one without the ads and it really functions quite like a tablet computer because of access to all the available apps.  I am so glad i bought this for my wife as an early Christmas present!

Reviews.Title: Worth the wait.
Reviews.Author: Sandra L Wood
Reviews.Content: This is my first tablet. I had been waiting since June for an announcement for the new Kindle.. I wanted something comparable to my friend's Ipad2, & less expensive.The only issue I have is  that you cannot get the Adobe Flash Player.. so if you're looking to watch videos from your FB, or FB games.. forget it. There are some games from FB that can be downloaded and played separately. I really miss the player.The graphics are so clear.It's very thin, and easy to figure out.Only one thing I don't understand, is that the speakers are on the back instead of the front. So while watching a movie I turn the volume up to the max. You can cup your hands around the speakers, and about triple  the volume.All in all , I am thrilled with the Kindle.Update: So its been a couple weeks with my first Kindle.Still loving it..except I do have 2 small complaints.. I didn't think the ad's would bother me.. but I have noticed they are popping up twice as much now. Even playing Angry Birds..the screen will go blank and a small ad will appear.I understand I can pay $15.00 to have it removed..I think I might. The other thing is when its charging the plug is at the bottom, so when you're playing an app that won't rotate..you have to be careful not to bend the plug.These items are not bad enough to return this Kindle!!

Reviews.Title: So far, so excellent.
Reviews.Author: JAZZY62
Reviews.Content: I am a long time techie and IT professional. Pound for Pound considering cost to quality this is one of the best buys I have experienced in recent years.  The hardware is very responsive and the Amazon ECO system is of course a great bonus. I bought it for entertainment purposes and the occasional email-personal APP use and it delivers flawlessly so far. The video is smooth and the sound is clear and precise. In summary as not to write a book, you will be pleased if you read what the description is prior to purchasing.  It delivers.The tablet is not a replacement for a laptop and never claimed to be, it does what it proclaims to do and does it well.  This tablet will not disappoint; highly recommended!

Reviews.Title: I just cant put it down!!
Reviews.Author: SpikeysMommy
Reviews.Content: LOVE IT, LOVE IT, LOVE IT!!!!!  This tablet is so easy to use,has a crystal clear screen,and when needed, the most incredible tech support available. My songs on Amazon's mp3 player download instantly,has millions of apps and games to choose from at the lowest prices imagineable,and as a Prime Member you can access movies and books, many of which are free!!  My Kindle provides me with hours of non-stop entertainment right at my fingertips. Now that I have purchased it, I can honestly say the only thing I want for Christmas are Amazon gift cards to add more games and songs to my Kindle Fire HD!!

Reviews.Title: Easy to travel with everywhere, excellent size viewing.
Reviews.Author: PAM
Reviews.Content: Love being able to share books and ability to tap into music suggestions.  Enjoy downloading games that I can have grandchildren enjoy with me on my tablet.  This is a new purchase so I'm still learning many neat areas of interest, but the screen size and speed are fantastic!  Strongly recommend the leather case with purchase; very secure.  At 70 years old, I have to admit - this allows me to enjoy reading, shopping and staying connected with family and friends. LOVE IT

Reviews.Title: First Impressions
Reviews.Author: John F. Kolacki
Reviews.Content: I'm coming over from a nook tablet so I have some experience using this type of device.First off it is very easy to setup,wi-fi,e-mail were quickly setup.I was up and running in about Five minutes.I can't figure out all the reviews that say this is difficult.No charger? who cares,most people already have something that works or they can buy one. Weight feels good,it feels like a solid device,nice design,it looks fantastic.Button placement and design is a little off-putting though,there could be some tactile feedback to improve them,I sometimes hit them when I don't want to,and can't find them when I need to,this will change with more use though I'm sure. Screen display is bloody amazing with video apps and pictures,and looks good web surfing and with E-books,although the screen is a fingerprint magnet. Sound is very good for this size of tablet,much better than my Nook. Web surfing works good so far,no crashes for me yet in 2 days of using.I was able to easily side load some apps and all work well including the nook app for my existing nook library(sorry Amazon). So far very happy with the Fire HD and not regretting the purchase.The One and Two star reviewers slamming the device for what it cannot do need a reality check.People,this is an entertainment device for movies,music,e-reading,web surfing,e-mail and game apps,it's not a laptop computer,do a little homework first and use some common sense,this is not rocket science.

Reviews.Title: I love it - Kindle Fire 8.9
Reviews.Author: B Jones "bookscover"
Reviews.Content: This Kindle is the real thing. Reading magazines and graphic novels in COLOR!! I have a first generation kindle. It's black + white and screen is not backlit. This Kindle fixed both and then went farther.I am still looking into the movies and tv series available using Amazon Prime.I can signin to Netflix too.I used Kindle Fire in the kitchen Thanksgiving making turkey dinner for hours,"watched" two movies.I am going to investigate audio books next.I discovered books with the Kindle I never would have read, and I didn't have to have a great bookstore nearby!

Reviews.Title: Sweet machine, but...
Reviews.Author: M. Joseph
Reviews.Content: This is a sweet little machine, but I had to return it after two weeks. I was very disappointed after having this item on back-order for over a month, then to receive it and having to return it because of a fundamental weakness in the power input jack. AMAZON was aware of this weakness in the architecture as many of the Kindle Fire 1st. Gen. were returned due to this same problem - no effort was made on the KF HD to correct this problem.

Reviews.Title: My fourth Kindle...
Reviews.Author: sjpatrick
Reviews.Content: Fourth Kindle, third Fire, second HD. All of my Kindles have given me great gadget joy, but the HD models came with one great flaw in hardware design: the placement of the charging port.These latter devices -- heck, the whole Fire line -- have been designed for media far beyond books. Specifically, video, which they all handle beautifully. The HD models, spectacularly. And take note of all, ALL of the covers that they sell for these models: they are all designed to allow the device to stand in landscape mode to avail themselves to the strength.My original Kindle Fire (first generation) looks a little it silly with the power plug coming out of its "side", but it functions perfectly that way. It stands in its pretty little (extra purchase) case and shows me video. Or plays music or games or even lets me read, but it stands naturally on its broad edge doing so.The HD models in their specifically designed cases though are awkward at best because the charging cable impedes resting the devices on their long edge: they "lean" on the cables instead. This causes imbalance and clumsiness and can cause undo wear on the charging connectors themselves.Fortunately, a ready solution presents itself in a different design for the charging cables. Make them with bent or hinged connectors so they don't simply jut out stupidly from the device and the device can then stand much more normally and the world will be perfect again.That one flaw is the only one that the Fire HD has to contend with, as far as I'm concerned.I ordered mine even before the whole ad-supported thing was an issue, the day it was announced in fact. I left that order intact as to not lose my place in line. I figured I'd deal with the $15 later. Having seen what all the fuss is about, it's mostly trivia. I'll be paying the $15 within a few days I'm sure, but it has largely been a on-issue.As for the device itself, with the aforementioned flaw aside, it is nothing short of spectacular.The display is stunning, the sound is surprisingly great, the networking is solid and the bluetooth range is exceptional. The touch screen is notably more responsive than the original Kindle Fire. Despite what I noticed in another review, setting up the AT&T; mobile service was a no-brainer.I had the presence of mind when I ordered this machine to go ahead and buy a wall socket charger, so charging it is nowhere near the headache that others have expressed. In fairness, this is one area where Amazon might have been a little more proactive and these models might have been better served by including this accessory, but I won't belabor this point.Overall, I am as delighted with both of my Fire HD purchases as I was with my first Kindle (keyboard model) and my first Kindle Fire. They all serve me books and music, but the Fires serve me video, which is what I am usually most hungry for. And they do it extremely well.The whole charge plug thing however does merit the docking of an entire star from this review.

Reviews.Title: As great as I thought it would be.
Reviews.Author: James Ganley
Reviews.Content: This is the 4th Kindle that I have bought for myself and I have bought a couple more as gifts. This Kindle is just what I expected to be and I am extremely happy with it so far. I cannot understand some of the 1 and 2 star reviews that people are giving it. It seems like most of the low reviews are based on the fact that the purchaser did not review the specs on the Kindle to know what they were getting. I know that every now and again someone is going to get a dud but with amazons awesome customer service they will have a new one at the door the next day. I have a hard time believing the reviews that say customer support did not help them in any way.I have the 7 inch Kindle fire and I thought that one was great but needed a few tweaks. I did not like the speakers, but I would wear headphones most of the time anyway. The speakers on the new Kindle Fire 8.9 are great, no trouble at all while watching a show. I thought that the WIFI was a bit slow on the fire, but i am really happy so far with this one. I have not done any browsing online yet but I did download a few TV episodes in HD today and I was pleased at how fast they were done. The screen is just awesome, great picture and very quick response on the touchscreen.
